title: 110_hr5992
content: The Act titled "First Time Property Owners Tax Credit Act of 2008" provides a refundable credit for first-time purchase of real property under section 36 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "First Time Property Owners Tax Credit Act of 2008" allows a 5 percent credit against the tax for first-time purchasers of real property in the U.S. The maximum credit is $1,500 ($3,000 for joint returns) with an inflation adjustment after 2008. The tax credit for first-time property owners in the U.S. is $1,500 ($3,000 for joint returns) with an inflation adjustment after 2008. The taxable income limitation applies if the taxpayer's income exceeds the maximum taxable income in the table under specific sections, reducing the dollar amounts for the following year accordingly. The tax credit for first-time property owners in the U.S. is reduced for married individuals filing a joint return if they did not file jointly the previous year. The term 'first-time purchaser' refers to individuals with no ownership interest in real property for the past 2 years. The tax credit for first-time property owners in the U.S. is reduced for married individuals filing a joint return if they did not file jointly the previous year. To qualify as a first-time purchaser, an individual must not have had ownership interest in real property for the 2-year period before acquiring the property. Married individuals filing jointly must both be first-time purchasers to claim the credit. The tax credit for first-time property owners is only allowable for first-time purchasers, with the credit amount allocated among individuals as prescribed by the Secretary. The total credits for all individuals cannot exceed a specified amount for those filing joint returns. The term 'purchase' refers to any acquisition not from a related person. The tax credit for first-time property owners is limited to first-time purchasers and the credit amount is allocated among individuals as prescribed by the Secretary. The term 'purchase' excludes acquisitions from related persons that would result in the disallowance of losses under specific sections. The tax credit for first-time property owners is limited to purchases made between January 1, 2008, and January 1, 2013. The purchase price is defined as the adjusted basis of the property when a binding contract is entered into. No double benefit is allowed, and the basis of the property is reduced by the amount of the credit allowed. The taxpayer must enter into a binding contract to purchase property between January 1, 2008, and January 1, 2013, to qualify for the tax credit. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code and United States Code to reflect this requirement. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 involves updating the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 by replacing the item related to section 36 with new items. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007 for first-time purchase of real property and overpayments of tax.
